children.value: These characterizations clearly indicate a relation between being projective and being definable in second order arithmetic using function quantifiers.
We have seen that the Borel sets of finite order correspond to the sets definable (from parameters) by formulas using only number quantifiers (

). A similar relation holds between projective sets and sets definable by formulas using both number and function quantifiers. In fact, the way we defined the projective hierarchy makes this easy to see.

Historically, however, the topological approach and the definability approach happened separately, the former devised by the Russian school of Souslin, Lusin, and others, while the effective approach was pursued by Kleene. Kleene named the sets in his effective hierarchy
sets, which to this day is a source of much confusion.

children.value: The proof is similar to the proofs of
) that all analytic sets are Lebesgue measurable and have the Baire property. Since these properties are closed under complements, it follows that the same holds for co-analytic (

children.html: Π11\PP{1}ΠΠ11​

children.value: ) sets. Analytic sets also have the perfect-set property, but if you worked out the exercise, you will see that the proof does not carry over to complements of analytic sets. Can we find a different proof?

Similarly, it does not seem impossible to extend the regularity properties (LM) and (BP) to higher levels of the projective hierarchy. We will soon see that there are metamathematical limits that prevent us from doing so.
Without explicitly mentioning it, up to now we have been working in

children.html: ZF\ZFZF

children.value: , Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory, plus a weak form of Choice (

children.html: ACω(NN)\AC_\omega(\Baire)ACω​(NN)

children.value: ). If we add the full Axiom of Choice (

children.html: AC\ACAC

children.value: ), we saw that the regularity properties do not extend to all sets. Solovay’s model of

children.html: ZF+DC\ZF+\DCZF+DC

children.value: shows that the use of a strong version of Choice is necessary for this.

On the other hand, the proofs gave us no direct indication how complex the non-regular sets we constructed are.
We will study a model of

children.html: ZF\ZFZF
Δ21\bDelta^1_2ΔΔ21​

children.value: set which neither is Lebesgue measurable nor has the Baire property. This, together with the Solovay model, shows we cannot settle in

children.html: ZF\ZFZF

children.value: alone the question of whether the projective sets are measurable or have the Baire property. We would have to add additional axioms.
A key feature in the construction of a non-measurable

children.html: Δ21\bDelta^1_2ΔΔ21​

children.value: set is the use of the well-ordering principle rather than the Axiom of Choice.
